bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, June 8, 1922

div1.p: Hanson discusses the political situation in Peru and his difficulties in dealing with local authorities.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, June 8, 1922
div1.opener:
I. H. B
DIRECTOR GENERAL
HENRY HANSON
M. D.
BAJO LOS AUSPICIOS DEL
GOBIERNO PERUANO Y LA
JUNTA INTERNACIONAL DE
SANIDAD DE ROCKEFELLER
FOUNDATION
Hanson
Campaña Sanitaria contra la Fiebre Amarilla en el Perú
OFICINA CENTRAL
AVENIDA PIEROLA 545 - TELEFONO 3428
LIMA -- PERU
June 8, 1922.
NUMERO
____
DR. H.R. Carter,
Washington, D.C.
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I received your letter written from the
Johns Hopkins Hospital and am very sorry to hear of your sciatic
trouble and that the old kink has been kicking up again. However
we hope that with the good care and treatment which you have there
you will soon be in good condition to continue with your big work
on the history of yellow fever and other writings on malaria. I
am ver anxiously looking forward to our chat on the Peruvian situ-
ation and other sanitary problems when I arrive in August.

In regard to the cable I sent up about your money,- I
sent this because I noticed that the exchange began rising and
on noting this I went to see Mr. Oehmichen, the new manager of the
Banco Mercantil Americano del Peru, expalaining to him the circum-
stances of your deposit. He told me that we better arrange for au-
thorization to convert this into dollars after the exchange had
risen sufficiently to justify doing so. He saud that he expected
the exchange to go up above four on account of the movement of
cotton, sugar and some other factors which were decidedly influen-
cing the exchange. The we in the cable was partly put in on account
of the part which the Manager of the bank played and because in our
code there was no code word correspoinding to the I. Yesterday the
exchange reached 4.03 and I am quite sure that it is going still
higher, however I will again consult my good banker friends before
making the conversion into dollars. It is a bit difficult to do
this because it is a sort of a gamble, and one can not tell when
it is the safest time to make the transaction.

In regard to the Salubridad, I find that there is an
enormous amount of work to be done here, some of it which can be
done, but much of it which can not be done on account of the politic-
al situation and more on account of the lack of funds. What I am
aiming to accomplish before I leave is to establish a more workable
regulation covering the duties and relations of the Médicos Sanitar-
ios Departamentales, Titulares, and the Municipal Health Departments.
Even if I do nothing else of note this will leave a very decided
benefit for the future, because it will make possible much work which
under existing conditions can not be done. In this I am simply using
and coordinating what they already have, hence arousing no very great
opposition by introducing a marked revolutionary change such as was
the case with the proposals which Wrightson had in mind. The Sanitaro
with whom I have talked the matter over are quite thoroughly in favor
of my plan and look upon it as opening up a possibility to them to
do something practical. Among many other faults with the present sys-
tem and organization, one of the most serious is that the men who we o
have have no workable regulations under which to operate.

Well this is just a note, it should only be about 7 or 8
weeks until I sail, so will reserve other things for our chat in USA.

With the warmest regards from all the family. When Ernstina
asks Virgil what Dr. Carter says, he (V) replies Ey, ey, ey,. I think they
are all looking forward to seeing GrandPa Carter.
